duck: Stout is a dark beer made using roasted malts or roast barley.

wiki.text:
'Stout' is a dark beer made using roasted malt or roasted barley, hops, water
and yeast. Stouts were traditionally the generic term for the strongest or
stoutest porters, typically 7% or 8%, produced by a brewery.<ref name="node">The
New Oxford Dictionary of English. Oxford University Press 1998 ISBN 0-19-861263-
X</ref><ref name="camra">[http://www.camra.org.uk/page.php?id=231 Porter and
Stout - CAMRA]</ref> In this sense a stout is not necessarily dark in colour
because there are also blonde stouts.<ref>http://zythophile.wordpress.com/2007/09/06/pale-
stout/</ref> There are a number of variations including Baltic porter, dry stout
and imperial stout. The name porter was first used in 1721 to describe a dark
brown beer popular with street and river porters of London that had been made
with roasted malts. This same beer later also became known as stout though the
word stout had been used as early as 1677.<ref name="E">[http://www.amazon.com/gp/reader/0937381446?p=S003#reader-
page Stout (Classic Beer Style Series, 10)]</ref> The history and development of
stout and porter are intertwined.<ref name="camra"/><ref>[http://www.beerhunter.com/documents/19133-
000041.html Michael Jackson's Beer Hunter - Porter casts a long shadow on ale
history<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
wiki.title: stout
